Description.val:
CHEMICAL & BIOLOGICAL DEFENSE PROGRAM (INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS):
Public Law 103-160, Section 1703 created a Joint Service Chemical and Biological Defense Program (CBDP) to address ever growing threats from the aggressive proliferation of chemical and biological weapons. Joint CBDP funds the development and procurement of Chemical and Biological Defense (CBD) Equipment to enhance the warfighter's ability to survive and complete their mission in a chemical biological contaminated environment. The Navy is responsible for the associated installation/integration and sustainment funds only. The Navy's requirement for Joint Biological Point Detection System (JBPDS), Improved Point Detection System/Lifecycle Replacement (IPDS/LR), Joint Biological Agent Identification and Diagnostic System (JBAIDS), Next Generation Chemical Detection (NGDS) System, Enhanced Maritime Biological Detection (EMBD) system and Dismounted Reconnaissance Sets, and Outfits (DRSKO) has been validated by CNO in associated Joint Operational Requirements Documents and/or Capability Production Documents.

Installation of Equipment
Funding is for installation of equipment including Fleet Modernization Program installations, installation of training equipment and installation of equipment in other shore facilities. Procurement of equipment is funded by the Joint
Service CBDP.

Detector installation costs can vary significantly, even within ship class,  depending  on installation location (East coast, West coast, OCONUS, etc.), if installation accomplished pier side or in a ship yard (i.e. availability type during which installation actually occurs), ship as built and as found conditions, and installation growth work (i.e. unplanned/unexpected work) driven by as found conditions.

[P3A / IPDS/LR]: The IPDS/LR (formerly SEACADS/IPDS) will improve the existing shipboard point detection system for detecting and identifying chemical nerve and blister agent contamination presence. Inventory objective for shipboard installations is 127.

[P3A - 2 / JBAIDS]: The JBAIDS will provide U.S. operating forces with a biological organism identification and diagnostic device that will identify and quantify biological organisms of operational concern and other pathogens of clinical significance for confirmatory and prognostic purposes. Inventory objective for shipboard JBAIDS installations is 23 and Refrigeration installations is 17.

[P3A - 4 / JBPDS BLK 1]: The JBPDS Block I will provide the Navy with automated, knowledge-based capability to detect and identify biological warfare agents in less than 20 minutes. The inventory objective for shipboard installations is 76.

[P3A - 5 / NGCD]: The Next Generation Chemical Detector (NGCD) is a technology replacement for the IPDS and IPDS-LR systems. The program consists of four variants for multiple applications; the Navy will be installating variant 1 for fixed chemical agent detection capability. The inventory objective for shipboard installations is 183.

[P3A - 6 / EMBD]: The Enhanced Maritime Biological Detection (EMBD) is a new acquisition program, which will provide lifecycle replacement kits for existing JBPDS system installations. Seven (7) ships require backfit of JBPDS, but Navy is awaiting JBPDS shells from Joint CBDP before installations can occur. EMBD Whole system is intended to install a JBPDS frame/shell with EMBD upgrade kit onto ships still requiring JBPDS. The inventory objective for shipboard installations is 7.

[P3A - 7 / IPDS-LR Heater]: The IPDS-LR Heater Upgrade provides the ability for IPDS-LR to function in various extreme environmental conditions that may cause system degradation and ultimately failure. This is a new, emergent requirement to ensure automated chemical agent detection is operationally available. The equipment development and procurement for this upgrade is funded out of the Joint Service CBDP Budget and is expected to be provided to Navy by mid FY19. The Navy is required to fund the integration and installation. Inventory objective for shipboard installations is 89.

[P3A - 8 / CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM DRSKO STOWAGE]: The CBRN Dismounted Reconnaissance Sets, Kits, and Outfits (DRSKO) consists of portable, commercial and government off-the-shelf equipment which provides Visit Board Search and Seizure (VBSS) forces with the capability to detect or deny the presence of Weapons of Mass Destruction (WMD) in support of WMD Interdiction (WMD-I) missions. This installation will install shelving and provide controlled access to support proper stowage of the Joint developed CBRN DRSKO system. The inventory objective for shipboard installations is 4.

[P3A - 9 / CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM EMBD UPGRADE KIT]: OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. The Enhanced Maritime Biological Detection (EMBD) kit is intended as a lifecycle replacement for the JBPDS system, and will include improved detection and identification capabilities. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service Chemical Biological Defense Program Budget.

Name.@footnote: IPDS-LR plan - The procurement costs are specifically referring to Installation and Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs as there are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. DSA costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship, excluding IPDS-LR for DDG Class ships which are class-wide drawings.   - FY18 installations total nine (9) vice previously planned eleven (11).  Congressional mark in FY18 of $380K necessitated need to lower planned installation quantities by two (2).  Ships to include three (3) LSD-41 Class ships at $207K each, three (3) CG-47 Class ships at $220K each, and three (3) DDG-51 Class ships at $190K each. Total installation cost for IPDS-LR in FY18 is $1,851K for nine (9) ships plus $403.8K for DSA costs.  - FY19 installations total seven (7) ships to include two (2) LSD-49 Class ships at $200K each, two (2) CG-47 Class ships at $220K each, one (1) DDG-51 Class ship at $190K each, and two (2) LCS-2 Class ship at $249.2K each. Total installation costs for FY19 is $1,528.4K plus $345K for DSA costs.  - FY20 installations total five(5) ships to include one (1) LDS-49 Class at $197K and four (4) CG-47 Class ships at $203.5K each. Total installation costs for IPDS-LR in FY20 is $1,011K plus $400K for DSA costs.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. CBRD Improved Point Detection System/Lifecycle Replacement (IPDS/LR) provides shipboard point detection system for detecting and identifying nerve and blister agent contamination presence. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service Chemical Biological Defense Program Budget.

[IPDS/LR] Remarks: A total of one hundred and seven (107) completed. DDG-106 started Q1 FY18, but will not officially finish until late Q3 FY18 when the system operational verification test (SOVT) can be accomplished.  Planned installations have increased from 125 at PB19 submission to 127.  Removed the  two (2) previously planned installations at the Aegis Ashore facilities in Romania and Poland since it was determined these facilities would keep their current capability until NGCD is fielded.  Added four (4) CG-47 Class ships back into the planned schedule due to delays in the Joint developed NGCD.  CGs added back into plan are CG-67, 68, 70, and 71.

Name.@footnote: There are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. The Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship.  - FY20 installations include one (1) LHA-6 Class ship at $90K.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. JBAIDS systems will identify and quantify biological organisms of operational concern and other pathogens of clinical significance for confirmatory and prognostic purposes. The CENTCOM HR urgent need (dated Aug 2009) modifies the JBAIDS ORD (dated May 2003) with the addition of detection capability for the 2009/A/H1N1 influenza. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service CBDP Budget P-1 Item Nomenclature: JBAIDS. Beginning in FY13, system will install with refrigeration unit.

[JBAIDS] Remarks: A total of twenty two (22) completed of twenty three (23) planned. The LHA 7 installation will occur during PSA in FY20. LHA 8 has successfully added JBAIDS to the baseline and should have the system installed during construction.

Description.val: OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy  Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. JBAIDS systems will detect and identify biological organisms of operational concern and other pathogens of clinical significance for confirmatory and prognostic purposes. The CENTCOM HR urgent need (dated Aug 2009) modifies the JBAIDS ORD (dated May 2003) with the addition of detection capability for the 2009/A/H1N1 influenza. This requires the installation of added support equipment, hard-wired freezers. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service CBDP Budget P-1 Item Nomenclature: JBAIDS.

Title.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM JBPDS BLK 1

Name.@footnote: The procurement costs are specifically referring to Installation and Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs as there are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. DSA costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship.  The LCS 4 and LCS 2 installs are expected to be more expensive than other JBPDS installs because both have partially installed systems that will need to be ripped out and relocated. - FY20 $200K for DSAs in preparation of installation in FY21 onboard LCS-4 and LCS-2. - FY21 Installations include two (2) LCS-2 Class ships at $455K each.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10F articulates U.S. Navy CBRD policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of Fleet Readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. JBPDS BLK I provides for improved biological agent detection and reporting. The JBPDS ORD (J2-B001-Revision 1, dated 7 January, 2002) validates the modification. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint CBDP Budget P-1 Item Nomenclature: (JP0100) JBPDS.

[JBPDS BLK 1] Remarks: A total of 74 completed. The last two planned installations are for LCS-2 and LCS-4. Both hulls had JBPDS partially installed by the ship builder during construction, but the system is inoperable. The LCS 2 & 4 JBPDS require removal and relocation to function properly. Previously, LCS-2 and LCS-4 were planned for installation in FY18 and FY19, but installations have since been rescheduled to FY21 to allow for higher priority ship alterations to occur, such as Fleet requested DRSKO stowage alterations on four (4) ships and IPDS-LR heater upgrade to prevent condensation in the system which could cause degradation of system performance and damage. JBPDS are now planned for removal and relocation in FY21 to make functional.

Name.@footnote: There are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. The Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. The Next Generation Chemical Detector (NGCD) provides shipboard point detection system for detecting and identifying nerve and blister agent contamination presence. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service Chemical Biological Defense Program Budget.

[NGCD] Remarks: The Next Generation Chemical Detector (NGCD) is a technology replacement for the IPDS and IPDS-LR systems. The program consists of four variants for multiple applications; the Navy will be installing variant 1 for fixed chemical agent detection capability. The inventory objective for shipboard installations is 185. Previously, installations were expected to start in FY22 with advance planning activities (DSA) to start in FY21, but recent Joint program delays now expect NGCD fielding to Navy to commence FY22, necessitating Navy change planned installations to start FY23.

Title.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM EMBD WHOLE SYSTEM

Name.@footnote: There are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. The Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of Ship Installation Drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. The Enhanced Maritime Biological Detection (EMBD) system is intended as a lifecycle replacement for the JBPDS system, and will include improved detection and identification capabilities. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service Chemical Biological Defense Program Budget.

[EMBD] Remarks: EMBD is a new acquisition program, which will provide lifecycle replacement kits for existing JBPDS system installations. The EMBD kit is intended to install within the existing JBPDS frame, reducing overall installation complexity and refurbishment unit costs. Labor for refurbishment of ships already equipped with the JBPDS system will be funded by the Joint Service Chemical Biological Program. However, there are seven (7) ships, previously nine (9), that were planned to receive JBPDS, but will not prior to EMBD entering the fleet. Therefore these seven (7) ships will receive EMBD Whole Systems, consisting of both the EMBD refurbishment kit and the overall EMBD/JBPDS shell. LCS-2 and LCS-4 were previously included in the EMBD count, but delays in EMBD development by  the Joint program necessitate removal and installation of JBPDS on these hulls to mitigate Warfighter risk. Installation of these  EMBD Whole systems is now projected to start in FY22 instead of FY21 as previously planned due to Joint CBDP EMBD Kit program delays. DSA costs will start to be incurred in FY21 for installation planning and drawing development.

ModificationTitle.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM IPDS-LR HEATER UPGRADE

Title.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM IPDS-LR HEATER UPGRADE

Name.@footnote: IPDS-LR Heater Upgrade plan - The procurement costs are specifically referring to Installation and Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs as there are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. DSA costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship.   - FY19 installations include seven (7) DDG-51 Class ships at $30K each plus $452.6K for DSA costs.  - FY20 funded installations total thirty-three (33).  Costs include two (2) LHD-1 Class ships at $31K each, three (3) LPD-17 Class ships at $31K each, two (2) LSD-41 Class ships at $31K each, four (4) LSD-49 Class ships at $31K each, ten (10) CG-47 Class ships at $31K each, six (6) DDG-51 Class ships at $31k each, two (2) LCS-1 Class ships at $31k each, and four (4) CVN-69 Class ships at $31K each. Total installations funded using FY20 OPN equals $1,023K plus $120K for DSA.

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy CBRD policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. CBRD Improved Point Detection System Heater Upgrade (IPDS-LR HU) provides the ability for IPDS-LR to function in various extreme environmental conditions that may cause system degradation and ultimately failure.  This is a new, emergent requirement to  ensure automated chemical agent detection is operationally available.  The equipment development and procurement for this upgrade is funded out of the Joint Service CBDP Budget and is expected to be provided to Navy by early FY19.  Navy must fund integration and installation.  DSA costs are expected to start early FY19 with installations to start in FY19.

[IPDS-LR Heater] Remarks: Eighty-nine (89) heater upgrades are currently planned and budgeted. Other ships will receive this capability when NGCD replaces IPDS-LR, which is expected to start fielding in FY23. Once heater upgrade is fully developed by the Joint Service CBDP, further refinement of integration and installation costs can be accomplished and inventory objective may be adjusted. Heater upgrade is currently in prototyping and testing stage. A procurement contract is expected to be awarded by the Joint Service CBDP shortly after system testing is complete.

ModificationTitle.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM DRSKO STOWAGE

Title.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM DRSKO STOWAGE

Name.@footnote: Dismounted Reconnaissance Sets, Kits, and Outfits (DRSKO) Stowage plan - The procurement costs are specifically referring to Installation and Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs as there are no equipment procurement costs with any detector system installed. DSA costs are for government engineering oversight/support in preparation for ship installation and ship class planning yards for engineering services which include ship check, development and approval of ship installation drawings (SIDs), Ship Selected Record changes, Bill of Material (BOM), onsite planning yard engineering support during installation to answer liaison action record (LARs), and other engineering services depending on the planning yard. DSA costs are generally funded up to one year prior to planned installation due to drawing development lead time and installation preparation efforts. These costs are ship specific since drawings are developed for each ship, not class of ship.   - FY18 installation includes one (1) DDG-51 Class at $141.2K.  Planned DSA cost are $260K.  - FY19 installations include one (1) LPD-17 Class ship and one (1) CG-47 Class ship at $150K each plus $130K for DSA costs.  - FY20 installation includes one (1) LSD-41 Class ship at $152K.
Name.val: 1.1.1) CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM DRSKO STOWAGE - NonOrganic

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified]:: Installation Name: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM DRSKO STOWAGE

Description.val:
OPNAVINST 3400.10G articulates U.S. Navy Chemical, Biological and Radiological Defense (CBRD) policy and establishes functional responsibilities to ensure the highest level of the Fleet readiness and warfighting sustainability in a CBR environment. Chemical Biological Radiological Nuclear Dismounted Reconnaissance Sets, Kits, and Outfits (CBRN DRSKO) provides Navy Boarding Teams personnel protection from current and emerging CBRN hazards through detection, identification, sample collection, decontamination, marking, and hazard reporting for CBRN threats.  Due to system size and storage requirements of equipment and materials, a ship alteration must be accomplished for adequate shelving, electrical power, ventilation, and stowage space security. The equipment procurement is funded out of the Joint Service Chemical Biological Defense Program Budget.

[CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM DRSKO STOWAGE] Remarks: A total of four (4) installations are currently planned.  One (1) for each of the following ship classes: DDG-51, LPD-17, LSD-41, and CG-47. This alteration will install shelving and provide controlled access to support proper stowage of the Joint developed CBRN DRSKO system. DDG class SIDs were previously developed and approved.  SIDs for the other three (3) classes will be developed to support FY19 and FY20 installations.

ModificationTitle.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM EMBD UPGRADE KIT

Title.val: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM EMBD UPGRADE KIT

Name.val: 1.1.1) CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM EMBD UPGRADE KIT - NonOrganic

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified]:: Installation Name: CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM EMBD UPGRADE KIT

Description.val: [CW001 CHEMICAL WARFARE PROGRAM EMBD UPGRADE KIT] Remarks: EMBD is a new acquisition program, which will provide lifecycle replacement kits for existing JBPDS system installations. The EMBD kit is intended to install within the existing JBPDS frame, reducing overall installation complexity and refurbishment unit costs. Labor for refurbishment of ships already equipped with the JBPDS system will be funded by the Joint Service Chemical Biological Program, however Navy must fund DSA and other incidental costs, to include planning yard and ship yard costs, to complete planned backfit upgrades. Due to delays in Joint developed EMBD kit, Navy is not expected to receive sufficent quantities of upgrade kits and be ready to install the equipment until FY23. DSA costs will start to be incurred in FY22 for installation planning and drawing development.
